summary: This is the FBI's Daily News Briefing for January 11, 2024, summarizing major news stories of interest to the Bureau. It covers a wide range of topics including election security, counterterrorism, criminal investigations, and Capitol violence news. A notable item mentions that Senate Judiciary Committee Republicans are pushing to subpoena the FBI for all records pertaining to Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell following a court document dump.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: FBI Director quoted multiple times discussing election security, deepfakes, foreign interference, and various threats including from China and Hezbollah.

persons.name: Paul Nakasone
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Director Wray in discussions about election security and deepfake threats.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in a news item stating Senate Judiciary Committee Republicans are pushing to subpoena the FBI for all records pertaining to him and Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Jeffrey Epstein as the subject of a potential Senate Judiciary Committee subpoena for FBI records.

persons.name: Bernie Sanders
persons.context: Urged by a bipartisan task force to hold a hearing on antisemitism on college campuses.

persons.name: Humzah Mashkoor
persons.context: An 18-year-old autistic teen arrested by the FBI for attempting to join ISIS after interacting with undercover agents.

persons.name: Alexander Lightner
persons.context: Florida man arrested by the FBI for threatening a 'mass casualty event' and found with white supremacist propaganda.

persons.name: Bob Menendez
persons.context: Sought dismissal of criminal bribery charges, arguing prosecutors 'distort reality'.

persons.name: Wenheng Zhao
persons.context: Sentenced for transmitting sensitive U.S. military information to a Chinese intelligence officer for bribes.

persons.name: Hunter Biden
persons.context: Expected to plead not guilty to federal tax charges in Los Angeles; also faces gun charges in Delaware.

persons.name: Alan W. Wilmer Sr.
persons.context: DNA evidence linked him to three killings in Virginia in the late 1980s, including cases associated with the 'Colonial Parkway murders'.

persons.name: Brian Dugan
persons.role: FBI Special Agent in Charge, Norfolk
persons.context: Commented on the DNA link in the Colonial Parkway murders case and appealed for public information.

persons.name: Duane Davis
persons.context: Charged with orchestrating the killing of Tupac Shakur; authorities are investigating his jailhouse calls.

persons.name: Arthur Hector Fernandez
persons.context: Arrested after videos surfaced showing him and others sexually assaulting toddlers at a Texas mall where he worked.

persons.name: Frank Dahlquist
persons.context: Montana fire chief charged with assaulting police officers during the Jan. 6 Capitol Riot.

persons.name: Stephen Horn
persons.context: Independent journalist sentenced to probation for entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.

persons.name: Ron Johnson
persons.context: Hosted a Capitol screening of an Epoch Times documentary about Jan. 6 and praised it.

persons.name: Shohini Sinha
persons.role: FBI Special Agent in Charge, Salt Lake City
persons.context: Released PSAs in eight languages to encourage hate crime reporting.

persons.name: Scot Peterson
persons.context: Lawsuit against him by Parkland school shooting families can proceed to trial for failing to intervene.

connections.description: Mentioned together as the subjects of a potential Senate Judiciary Committee subpoena for all FBI records pertaining to them.
Frequently mentioned together in the context of coordinating on election security and cyber threats.

events.title: FBI Daily News Briefing Published
events.description: The FBI's Office of Public Affairs distributes its daily compilation of news stories relevant to the Bureau's work.

events.title: Senate Judiciary Probe into Epstein FBI Records
events.description: Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee are pushing to subpoena the FBI for all records pertaining to Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell after a federal court finished unsealing documents.

events.title: Epstein Arrest and Death
events.description: Mentioned in passing: FBI agents raided Epstein's properties after his arrest in early 2019; his death in a federal jail cell was ruled a suicide.

events.title: January 6 Capitol Riot
events.description: Multiple news items reference the Jan. 6 attack, including arrests, prosecutions, a documentary screening, and analysis of Trump's rhetoric.

locations: Little St. James, U.S. Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Senate Judiciary Committee Republicans are seeking to subpoena the FBI for all records related to Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell following a recent court document dump.

The briefing notes that Epstein's victims had sent a letter to the FBI demanding an investigation into the bureau's early handling of the case, with claims they flagged Epstein's crimes as early as 1996.
FBI Director Christopher Wray extensively discussed election security threats, including deepfakes and foreign interference from nations like China and Russia.
The document is an FBI internal news digest, not a primary investigative file, but it highlights ongoing political and media interest in the Epstein case.
Multiple other criminal investigations are summarized, including cases of terrorism, espionage, and the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, showing the breadth of FBI activity.
